info.title: MythX API
info.description:
[MythX](https://mythx.io) is a security analysis API for Ethereum
smart contracts. It powers tools that bring security into the
smart contract SDLC.

Join the MythX community at [MythX
Discord](https://discord.gg/kktn8Wt) for more information.

This document describes the API interface to MythX. It is entended
for Dapp developers who wish to bring the power MythX to their
Dapps.

# API Authentication Methods

MythX API implements [JWT](#section/API-Authentication-Methods/JWT) and
[MetaMask](#section/API-Authentication-Methods/MetaMask) authentication schemes.
For better security user credentials (User ID / Ethereum address / email +
password) are only used to start JWT sessions

<!-- ReDoc-Inject: <security-definitions> -->

# User Roles and Permissions

## Overview

MythX user roles and permissions are string tokens recognized by API server,
and utilized to control user access to different API functionalities, as well
as to alter API behavior for user with different rights.

User roles assigned to each user can be found inside the `roles` array of user
object (see [GET /users/{id}](#operation/getUserById)). Each role represents a
set of user permissions. The exact mapping between roles and permissions is
stored server-side and may be changed as needed, thus allowing to tune API
behavior for users with certain roles without chaning user roles.

When a user hits API, his roles are mapped into sets of permissions that
correspond to these roles currently, and all these permissions are merged
into a single permissions set. Endpoint controllers then check as necessary
for the presence of required permissions in that set, to decide how different
features should work for the user, or whether corresponding functionality
should work for the user at all. To check permissions currently granted to
the user by his roles use
[GET /users/{id}/permissions](#operation/getUserPermissions).

When a new [JWT session](#section/API-Authentication-Methods/JWT) is opened
by [POST /auth/login](#operation/login), it is possible to narrow down user
permissions allowed for that session. For example, it allows to use JWT tokens
as API keys for tools, that only allow to run analyses, and retrieve their
results, but do not allow to modify user details, etc. To check user
permissions requested, and granted in the current JWT session see
[GET /auth/session/permissions](#operation/getSessionPermissions).

For convenience, [GET /auth/login](#operation/login) and
[GET /auth/refresh](#operation/loginRefresh) endpoints also return
information on the permissions.

## Valid User Permissions

**MythX Usage Allowances**
- `NO_CACHE_LOOKUP` - Allows to use `noCacheLookup` option in analysis
  requests.
- `ANALYSES_LOOKUP_OWN` - Permits to look up your own past analyses, using
  [GET /v1/analyses](#operation/listAnalyses).

**Account Management Permissions**
- `CREATE_USERS_ADMIN` - Allows to create new users with `admin` role,
  as well as grant / take this role for created accounts.
- `CREATE_USERS_REGULAR` - Allows to create new regular users,
  as well as grant / take this role for created accounts.
- `CREATE_USERS_PARTNER` - Allows to create new users with `parnter` role,
  as well as grant / take this role for created accounts.
- `CREATE_USERS_TRUSTED` - Allows to create new users with
  the `trusted_user` role, as well as grant / take this role for created
  accounts.
- `CREATE_USERS_WITHOUT_ROLES` - Allows to create new user accounts.
- `CHANGE_PASSWORD_OWN` - Permits to change your own user password.
- `USER_LOOKUP` - Allows to lookup accounts of other users.

**Misc Permissions**
- `USERS_ANALYSES_STATS_LOOKUP` - Allows to fetch internal stats on MythX
  usage and performance.

get.description:
Generates authentication challenge.

At least one of query parameters must be provided, and it will determine
the type of challenge to generate. Currently, only challenges based on
Ethereum address of the user are supported, for
[MetaMask](#section/API-Authentication-Methods/MetaMask) authentication scheme.
Additional challenge types might be added in future.

**Challenge Types**

- Challenge based on Ethereum address. Generated when **ethAddress**
  query parameter is provided.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description:
Type of the challenge to generate.

- **one_time** allows just a single use of challenge response for
  authentication of a subsequent API call, within 10 minutes after
  generation of the challenge. After the first use the challenge is
  revoked. It is also revoked if not used within 10 minutes.

- **short_lived** allows to use the challenge response unlimited
  number of times within 10 minutes after the challenge generation.

200.description:
Returns two objects describing the banner to be shown in the MetaMask
dialog and the challenge hash.

type.description: data type of the element, string for both

name.description: name of the element, one of banner or challenge

value.description: value of the element, banner text or challenge hash

post.description:
Generates a pair of access and refresh JWT tokens for
[JWT authentication scheme](#section/API-Authentication-Methods/JWT).

It supports two operation modes, described below. In both modes,
`jwtLifetimes.access` and `jwtLifetimes.refresh` parameters of request body
allow to customize the lifetime of generated tokens. `permissions` parameter
allows to narrow down
[user permissions](#section/User-Roles-and-Permissions) granted by API
for that session.

- **MetaMask login** - follow
  [MetaMask authentication](#section/API-Authentication-Methods/MetaMask)
  to request and reply the authentication challenge. The challenge responce
  should be passed to this login endpoint inside the `Authorization` HTTP
  header.

- **User credentials login** - Login by username and password. The username
  may be either of:
  - MythX User ID (assigned by MythX API to any registered user);
  - Ethereum address, if user account is associated with an address;
  - A verified email address, if user account is associated with an
    email address, and that address has been verified by visiting
    the verification link in the verification email sent by API each
    time when user email is set or modified.

jwtLifetimes.description:
Custom JWT session lifetimes.

**Beware:** Longer JWT lifetimes decrease session security.

permissions.description:
User permissions. For details see
[User Roles and Permission](#section/User-Roles-and-Permissions).

ethAddress.description: An alias of `username` for backward compatibility.

userId.description: An alias of `username` for backward compatibility.

jwtLifetimes.description:
Custom JWT session lifetimes.

**Beware:** Longer JWT lifetimes decrease session security.

jwtTokens.title: JWT Tokens
jwtTokens.description: Holds a pair of JWT authentication tokens.

access.description: Access token. Valid for 10 minutes it permits to authenticate into API.

refresh.description:
Refresh token. Valid for one month it permits to refresh corresponding
access token.

owned.description: All permissions given to the user by his roles.

requested.description:
Permissions requested for the current session. `null` value means that all
owned permissions have been requested, and `[]` means that it has been
requested to open the session without any permissions.

granted.description:
User permissions granted for this session. There is no
guarantee that they stay the same during the session, as
they are re-evaluated on each API call, as an intersection
between the array of pemissions requested upon the login,
and the array of permissions granted to the user by his
roles.

get.description:
Lists analyses groups.

To see his own groups, the user needs `Analysis Groups` feature enabled.

`dateFrom` and `dateTo` parameters are defined in such way that query matches
any groups that were in progress between the specified timestamps.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: Pagination offset (number of groups to skip).

parameters.name: createdBy
parameters.description: Filter by MythX user ID of the group creator.

parameters.name: groupName
parameters.description:
Search by the group name.

Partial match will be supported eventually, but is not implemented yet.

parameters.name: dateFrom
parameters.description: List groups completed after this time.

parameters.name: dateTo
parameters.description: List groups created before this time.

parameters.name: mainSource
parameters.description: The JavaScript regular expression to match against the main source name.

parameters.name: projectId
parameters.description: List groups belonging to the projectId

200.description: Returns matching groups (up to 20 records a time).

groups.description: Up to 20 matching groups after the `offset`.

id.description: The group ID to manage the group, and add new analyses inside it.

name.description: User-provided group name. Empty values mean no name provided.

completedAt.description:
If all analyses in the group are completed, this is the timestamp when
the last pending analysis has been completed.

progress.description:
Estimated progress of the group analsis.

At the moment it is defined as the percentage of completed and failed
analyses relative to all analyses in the group. It may be changed later
to weight analyses by their estimated duration.

mainSourceFiles.description: Main source files of all analyses in the group.

numAnalyses.description: Counts of grouped analyses by their status.

total.description: All analyses in the group.

projectId.description: Optional. Project ID this group is attached to

total.description: The total number of groups matching the query.

post.description:
Creates a new analysis group. Interrelated analyses can be added to a group
using the `groupId` parameter of [POST /analyses](#operation/submitAnalysis) endpoint.
MythX platform provides additional analysis reporting features for groupped
analyses. The `seal_group` command of [POST /analysis-groups/{groupId}](#operation/analysisGroupOperation)
endpoint seals the group, informing API that no further analyses will be
added to the group. For analyses submitted without `groupId`, MythX
automatically creates sealed groups containing single analyses.

The ability to create analysis groups requires the `Analysis Groups` feature enabled.

The request body payload is optional, and allows to provide additional meta
information about the group.

groupName.description:
Optional. User-specified group name. It can be
a string, up to 256 symbols long, and must be unique amoung
all groups previously created by the user. Empty string values
are treated as no group name provided.

id.description: The group ID to manage the group, and add new analyses inside it.

name.description: User-provided group name. Empty values mean no name provided.

completedAt.description:
If all analyses in the group are completed, this is the timestamp when
the last pending analysis has been completed.

progress.description:
Estimated progress of the group analsis.

At the moment it is defined as the percentage of completed and failed
analyses relative to all analyses in the group. It may be changed later
to weight analyses by their estimated duration.

mainSourceFiles.description: Main source files of all analyses in the group.

numAnalyses.description: Counts of grouped analyses by their status.

total.description: All analyses in the group.

projectId.description: Optional. Project ID this group is attached to

post.description:
Executes specified operation on the analysis group.

- `seal_group` – Seals the group. API will forbid to add any new
  analyses into the group, and it may peform some final operations on
  the group reports, which are possible only after completion of all
  analyses.

- `add_to_project` – Attaches specified group to the project

- `remove_from_project` – Detaches specified group from the previously attached project

projectId.description: Project ID to attach the group to

get.summary: Get PDF Report for Analyses Group
get.description: Get a PDF report for a given group. The PDF contains a list of vulnerabilities and other information about the submitted analyses and group itself. By default at success client will be redirected to the URL containing PDF report

parameters.name: download_link
parameters.description: Return JSON with download link instead of redirect. (Link's TTL is 5 minutes)

parameters.name: share_link
parameters.description: Return JSON with sharing link. (Link's TTL is 30 days)

200.description: Success - A PDF containing information regarding the analyses in group and group itself.

shareLink.description: URL to download a report with 30 days TTL

downloadLink.description: URL to download a report with 5 minutes TTL

get.description:
Lists analyses visible to the user, at most 20 records a time,
sorted by submission time from the most recent to the oldest
ones. Use **offset** query parameter for results pagination. Use
**dateFrom** and **dateTo** query parameters to filter by analysis
submission timestamps.

Dates are specified using ann [ISO 8601 Date](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) string

Example Date Strings
--------------------
* `2018-11-20`,
* `2018-11-20T23:13:12`,
* `2018-11-20T23:13:12+00:00`
* `2018-11-20T23:13:12.177Z`

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: Pagination offset. Number of records to skip.

parameters.name: dateFrom
parameters.description: Submission time filter. Restricts results to analyses submitted after this time. Unset by default.

parameters.name: dateTo
parameters.description: Submission time filter. Restricts results to analyses submitted before this time. Unset by default.

parameters.name: mainSource
parameters.description: The JavaScript regular expression to match against the main source name.

analyses.description: Up to 20 matching analysis after the **offset**.

analysisMode.description:
`quick` will perform quick time-limited analysis. `full` performs a much more complete and longer-running analysis.

`full` mode requires `FULL_ANALYSIS` permission which is granted to
paid users.

or at the moment of submission, if this analysis is still queued.

Mythril core version at the moment of analysis execution;

Number of source files provided for the analysis. It is calculated based

post.description:
Submits Solidity contract(s) for vulnerability analysis and returns
created analysis record. It is possible to conduct a partial analysis 
on a contract by only submitting its creation bytecode or its source code
in their respective schema fields. **Fill out both fields to conduct a 
complete analysis**.
The _uuid_ field of the response should be used in subsequent calls to:

* [GET /analyses/{uuid}](#operation/getAnalysis) and
* [GET /analyses/{uuid}/issues](#operation/getAnalysisIssues) to

check analysis status, metadata, and the list of detected issues.

In addition to the JSON fields listed below, we allow additional fields. For example, truffle artfics will have an additional `abi` attribute.

The request format is equivalent to the output of:
```console
$ solc --pretty-json --combined-json ast,bin,bin-runtime,srcmap,srcmap-runtime
```
with the exception of the following field name changes which follow Truffe conventions:
  * `bin` → `bytecode`
  * `bin-runtime` → `deployedBytecode`
  * `srcmap` → `sourceMap`
  * `srcmap-runtime` → `deployedSourceMap`

groupId.description:
Analysis group ID. Grouped analyses can be retrieved from
[GET /analyses](#operation/listAnalyses) using `groupId` query parameter.
If no group ID is specified, a random unique one will be generated by API
itself. Must match a group created beforehand by
[POST /analysis-groups](#create-analysis-group)

groupName.description:
Analysis group name. Grouped analyses can be retrieved from
[GET /analyses](#operation/listAnalyses) using `groupName` query
parameter. The group with this name is automatically created, if
user has analysis grouping permission, otherwise analysis is added
to the group (must be non-sealed).

The default name (empty string) means no group name is provided.

noCacheLookup.description:
Optional. When `true` API won't look into the cache of past analyses, and
always will run a new analysis for this request. The using of cache has no
other side effects beside saving the runtime, thus this option is intended
only for benchmarking, API health control, and debuging purposes.
Itrequries `NO_CACHE_LOOKUP` permission to use, which is granted only to
MythX team members.

[submit Smart Contract analysis request](#operation/submitAnalysis).
In the submission, a _uuid_ was returned, which should be used in the url for
this request.
When analysis **status** is `Finished`,
[GET /analyses/{uuid}/issues](#operation/getAnalysisIssues) may be
used to list detected vulnerabilities.

200.description:

It can be one of:
* `Queued`: The analysis request is in a backlog queue of analysis requests to be processed.
* `Running`: The analysis request is currently running MythX analysis.
* `Error`: There was some error that terminated analysis processing. Check the `error` field for details about the problem.
* `Finished`: Analysis has finished. Using the `uuid` field in the response issue a request to the get the issue results using
   another call to get [Analysis results](#operation/getAnalysis).

parameters.name: projection
parameters.description:
Optional query projection. It specifies which fields to include or
exclude from the endpoint response. It can be either an URL-encoded
string, or object.

In the string form, it should be a whitespace-separated list of input
paths to include into the response, e.g. `bytecode mainSource`.
Alternatively, it can be a list of input paths to exclude from
the response, if the paths are prefixed by `-`, e.g.
`-mainSource -sources`. The value must be either entirely inclusive,
or exclusive, and it must be URL encoded as an URL query parameter.

In the object form the inclusive, or exclusive projections should look
like `{"bytecode": 1, "mainSource": 1}`,
and `{"mainSource": 0, "sources": 0}`. Some more complex projection
operations are supported, following the
[MongoDB projection syntax](https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/project-fields-from-query-results/).

mainSource.description: MainSource is the path to the Solidity file that is provided to the compiler as input.

sources.description: Sources map containing objects that each map to *at least one of* `source` or `ast` field to the respective contents.

contractName.description: The Smart Contract name. Note that in Solidity this is name is case sensitive.

bytecode.description:
The bytecode and additional code to get the code placed on the blockchain; in other words, the code of the contract constructor.
Note: in solc's JSON this is called `bin`. See also [solc bin vs. bin-runtime](https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/13086/solc-bin-vs-bin-runtime).

deployedBytecode.description:
The bytecode that is placed on the blockchain. Note: in solc's JSON this is called `bin-runtime`.
This is distinct from bytecode described above.

sourceMap.description:
Source map for the `bytecode` field. See Solidity's [Source
Mappings](https://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/v0.5.2/miscellaneous.html#source-mappings)
for how the Solidity compiler, `solc` defines this.

deployedSourceMap.description:
Source map for the `deployedBytecode` field. See Solidity's [Source
Mappings](https://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/v0.5.2/miscellaneous.html#source-mappings)
for how the Solidity compiler, `solc` defines this.

sourceList.description: The list of files that are being mapped to in the `sources` field.

version.description:
Version information that may be produced by the compiler or system that
produced the Smart Contract code. For example, in a Smart Contract compiled
via `solc`, version 0.5.2, it might be `0.5.2+commit.1df8f40c.Linux.g++`.

analysisMode.description:
`quick` will perform quick time-limited analysis. `full` performs a much more complete and longer-running analysis.

`full` mode requires `FULL_ANALYSIS` permission which is granted to
paid users.

get.description:
Lists registered API users. Allows to lookup users by email and
Ethereum addresses.

For users with no `USER_LOOKUP` permission this endpoint only finds their
own user objects.

Returns at most 20 users in a single response. Use the `offset` query
parameter for pagination.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: Pagination offset. The number of records to skip.

parameters.name: ethAddress
parameters.description: Filter users by Ethereum address fragments.

parameters.name: roles
parameters.description:
Filter users by API roles, stored in DB (does not account for
any additional roles given temporarily by subscriptions, etc.).

oneOf.description: If a single string is provided, API will return users having this role among their roles.

items.description: If a string array is provided, API will return all users having at least a single role from the provided array.

total.description: Total number of matching users.

users.description: Up to 20 matching user object after the **offset**

createdBy.description: If this user has been created by another user, this field holds creator's user ID. Otherwise it is `null`.

createdByPartner.description: `true` if this user has been created by a partner, `false` otherwise.

creatorLabel.description: If this user has been created by another user, this field will contain the value of creator's `label` field.

verified.description: A flag specifying whether the currently set email address has been verified.

label.description: Optional label, visible to the user, and editable by the user. It is also exposed to the users created by this user as `creatorLabel` field in their user objects.

mustChangePassword.description:
Indicates that user must change password before he will be allowed to use
most of API functionality.

ownerPartnerId.description:
User ID of the partner responsible over this account, if any. The value
of this field is used to aggregate usage stats of end-user accounts
related to each partner, for partner billing, and book-keeping purposes.
- For user accounts created by partners themselves, this value is force
  set equal to the partner ID, thus it is equal to `createdBy` value;
- When a MythX admin creates an account to pass it to a partner,
  the admin is responsible to set the correct partner ID here.

ownerPartnerLabel.description: If this user account is owned by a partner, this field will contain the value of partner's `label` field.

privateLabel.description: Optional label, invisible to the user. This label is only visible to, and editable by MythX admins, and also to users up in the user tree (i.e. those who created this user, those who created them, etc.)

newsletter.description: `true` if user wants to receive newsletters, `false` otherwise.

serviceNotifications.description: `true` if user agrees to receive service notifications, `false` otherwise.

The following user roles exist in MythX plaform as of now:

- `admin` - Gives all possible permissions. It is only intended for core
  members of MythX team.

- `regular_user` - Gives permission for regular API usage.

- `partner` - Gives permission to create new privileged and regular users.

- `trusted_user` - Gives permission to fetch internal platform usage
  statistics.

post.description:
Creates a new user.

- **Creation of a new user by a parent user**.

  The parent user must have necessary permissions
  ([GET /v1/users/{id}/permissions](#operation/getUserPermissions)).
  Currently, `CREATE_USERS_ADMIN`, `CREATE_USERS_REGULAR`,
  `CREATE_USERS_TRUSTED`, and
  `CREATE_USERS_WITHOUT_ROLES` permissions allow to create users with
  corresponding roles, as well as further give and take corresponding
  roles of created users.

  The only obligatory request field is the `password` to set on the created
  user account.

- **Self-registration**

  This endpoint allows users to self-register at [MythX Website](https://mythx.io).
  There are 2 options available:
    - Self-registration without Metamask
    - Self-registration with Metamask

  If the [MetaMask authentication scheme](#section/API-Authentication-Methods/MetaMask) is used then
  the second option becomes implicitly selected.

  - **Without [MetaMask](https://metamask.io/)**

    As no `ethAddress` is provided a new user will be created without any attached `ethAddress`
    (one can attach it [later](#operation/userAction)).

    In this case it is obligatory to provide at least the following required
    parameters: `password` (to set on the created user account), `termsId`, and `gReCaptcha`.

    `email`, if provided, must be unique among registered users.
    It won't be used by API until verification
    (*the exact details to be added*).

  - **With [MetaMask](https://metamask.io/)**

    A new user will be attached `ethAddress`
    provided by [MetaMask authentication scheme](#section/API-Authentication-Methods/MetaMask).

    In this case it is obligatory to provide at least the following required parameters:
    `password` (to set on the created user account), `termsId`,
    and `gReCaptcha`.

    `email`, if provided, must be unique among registered users.
    It won't be used by API until verification
    (*the exact details to be added*).

the newly created user will be counted for that parnter for billing and
book-keeping purposes.

post.description:
Executes one of generic operations on the specified user account:

- **Change Password** allows to change user password.
  Password must be different from previously used passwords.

  This function supports a direct login with user credentials, hence
  the optional `password` and `username` fields in the request. They
  work the same as they would in
  [POST /auth/login](#operation/login).

  This function has two operation modes:
  - Authenticated call to change user password;
  - A call without authentication, which provides a reset code issued
    previously by
    [POST /users/password-recovery](#operation/passwordRecovery)
    call.

- **Initialization of Email Verification**: (re-)starts email verification
  flow. API will check that user email is set, reset its status to
  to unverified, and send an email with the verification link to
  the user's email.

- **Update User Details** allows to update:
  - User first name;
  - User last name;

  Requires JWT or MetaMask authentication. Currently, it only allows
  to change your own details only.

- **Update User Preferences** allows to update:
  - **Newsletter Subscription**

- **Change Ethereum Address** allows to update (or set if initially one was not set) user's corresponding `ethAddress`.

- **Remove Ethereum Address** allows to remove user's corresponding `ethAddress`.

authentication is not required by this action.

your user and subscription types or the maximum request allowed per client and
second.

example.error:
Exceeded plan limit: 10,000 requests in a day; limit will reset in a day;
 Exceeded usage limit; please try again in 24H or upgrade your plan

500.description:
Internal server error — An unexpected error happened at the server
side when trying to fulfil your request.

example.error: Internal server error

get.description:
Serves real-time and historic statistics on API usage. The heavy-lifting
calculation of stats is done continiously by a background API thread, and
the results are stored to the database. This endpoint just looks up for
requested records already existing in the database, and returns up to 25
of them (pagination is supported). Results are sorted and served
chronologically from the most recent to the oldest ones.

For most of the time API will keep all statistics fresh, outdated at most by
~1 minute from the current moment. Larger lags are possible when a newly
deployed API version triggers re-evaluation of past statistics. In that case
the real-time updates of recent stats are paused until the re-evaluation is
completed. By design, this does not cause any data loses.

schema.description:
The type of stats to return.

- `detected-issues` - Counts of detected issues by SWC type,
  severity, etc.

- `partners` - Statistics on partner-controlled accounts of end users.
  Currently these include counts of created and activated end user
  accounts. An account is counted activated at the moment it sends
  in the first analysis request. Notice that `users-analyses` stats
  include counts of analyses submitted from end user accounts
  controlled by each partner. To fetch these stats users must
  have `STATS_LOOKUP.PARTNERS` permission.

- `users-analyses` - generic stats on users and analyses that are
  deduces mostly from scanning _analyses_ collection in API database.
  Users MUST have `STATS_LOOKUP.USERS_ANALYSES` permission to fetch
  these stats.

Stats interval, i.e the time range covered by a single record in
the response. In other words, requesting `ONE_DAY` stats you will get
an array of objects, each describing a single day. Other values are
self-explanatory.

For a reasonalbe use of database space, daily stats are available for
~3 last years, hourly stats for ~1 last month, five-minutes stats for
~3 last days.

Filters requested statistics records by their interval start,
i.e. all returned objects will describe intervals starting after
`from` timestamp.

Filters requested statistics records by their interval starts,
i.e. all returned objects will describe intervals starting prior
`to` timestamp.

Response pagination: the specified number of records will be omitted
from the response (matching records in the response are sorted
chronologically from the most recent to the oldest).

Specifies the minimal revision number of stat records that may be
included into the response. See description of response format for
the meaning of _revision_ number. In practice, statistics records of
the same type and with different revisions may co-exist only shortly
after an API redeployment that caused re-evaluation of past stats
data. Once re-evaluation is completed, all existing records of that
type end up updated to the latest revision.

from.description: Start of the interval described by this statistics object.

interval.description:
Length of the interval described by this statistics object.
End of the interval is either `from + interval`, or
`createdAt` (see below).

createdAt.description:
The last time this statistics object was updated. This
timestamp can be before `from + interval` which means that
the interval has not finished yet, and the object represents
the most recent data for interval, that will be updated,
typically once per minute. Once `createdAt` is after
`from + interval` the object represents the final values
for that interval, that may only be re-evaluated later
if a new API version introduces a new revision (see below)
for statistics of that `type` (see below).

type.description:
Type of statistics held by this object, i.e. describes
payload type of `data` object field (see below).

revision.description:
Revision of statistics data aggregated into this object.
Statistics data of each `type` has independent revision
numbers, which are integer values that are typically
incremented each by 1 each time any changes are introduced
into calculation logic behind these stats. Update of the
revision number causes an automatic re-evaluation of all
existing statistics of that `type` right after API
re-deployment. Until the re-evaluation is completed,
the objects with previous revision(s) and the new
revision may co-exist in the database, and in the
API responses. A client may use `minRevision` query
parameter, if it need to guarantee that only fresh
revisions are included into the response.

data.description:
The actual statistics payload that describes the interval
staring from the timestamp `from` and ending at the time
`from + interval`, or `createdAt`, whatever is the earliest.
The actual format of this object is defined by the `type`
field (see above).

oneOf.description: Holds stats on partner controlled accounts of end users.

PARTNER_ID.description:
Holds data on the specific partner. The `PARTNER_ID` is a placeholder for
partner ID, the real data will have a key for each registered partner
account.

label.description: Partner's `label`. Note that this label is visible to, and editable by the partner himself, unlike `privateLabel` which can be looked up separately in the user account, if looked up with sufficient permissions.

activatedOwnedAccounts.description: Count of activated end user accounts owned by the partner.

totalOwnedAccounts.description: Count of all user accounts onwed by the partner.

oneOf.description: Holds general statistics on users and analyses.

numUsers.description:
Different user counts: number of active and trial users, number of newly
registered users, total amount of registered users, etc.

total.description: The total number of registered users at the interval end.

new.description: The number of new users registered within the interval.

activeIn5min.description:
The average number of active users in a five-minutes time period within
the interval. A user is counted active if he has submitted at least a single
analysis request within the interval. If interval is shorted than five
minutes, the value equals to the number of active users in that interval.

activeInHour.description:
The average number of active users in a one hour time period within
the interval. A user is counted active if he has submitted at least a single
analysis request within the interval. If interval is shorted than one hour,
the value equals to the number of active users in that interval.

activeInDay.description:
The average number of active users in a one day time period within
the interval. A user is counted active if he has submitted at least a single
analysis request within the interval. If interval is shorted than one day,
the value equals to the number of active users in that interval.

activeInMonth.description:

numAnalyses.description: Counts of analyses by type, state, and origin.

allOf.description: Counts of all analyses, e.g. both `full` and `quick`.

total.description: The total number of ever requested analyses, from the beginning of MythX era till the interval end.

new.description: The number of new analyses requested within the interval.

cacheHits.description: Counts of analyses served from the cache.

total.description: The total number of analyses ever served from the cache, i.e. right after submission API detected that the same inputs were already analysed with the same tool versions for the same or different users, thus it just serves the same results right away, without invoking the actual analysis.

new.description: The number of analyses served from the cache within the interval.

total.description: The total number of ever failed analyses at the interval end.

new.description: The number of analyses failed within the interval.

inProgress.description: Counts of analyses failed while in the _In Progress` state.

total.description: The total number of analyses, at the interval end, ever failed while in _In Progress_ state.

new.description: The number of analyses failed within the interval while in the _In Progress_ state.

inQueue.description: Counts of analyses failed while in queue, i.e. after they have been received by API, but before API received and stored the confirmation from Maestro about starting the analysis.

total.description: The total number of analyses, at the interval end, ever failed while being in the queue.

new.description: The number of analyses failed within the interval, while being in the queue.

finished.description: Counts of successfully finished analyses, i.e. those that have not been served from cache, and have not failed.

total.description: The total number of ever completed analyses.

new.description: The number of analyses successfully completed within the interval.

total.description: The total number of analyses queued at the interval end. Note, unlike other `total` fields, this one does not count all analyses even been to the queue, but analyses that were in the queue exactly at the end of the interval.

average.description:
The average number of queued analyses at any time within
the interval. For computational efficiency, for intervals
under five minutes it is just set equal to the `total` (above)
queue size at the current interval end, for larger intervals
this value is estimated based on the total queue size at the
end of each 5-minutes sub-interval.

new.description: The number of analyses added to the queue within the interval.

total.description: The total number of analyses being in progress at the interval end. Note, unlike other `total` fields, this one does not count all analyses even been in the _In Progress_ state, but it counts the actual number of analyses that were _In Progress_ at the interval end.

average.description:
The average number of in progress analyses at any time within
the interval. For computational efficiency, for intervals
under five minutes it is just set equal to the `total` (above)
number of analyses in progress at the current interval end, for
larger intervals this value is estimated based on the total queue
size at the end of each 5-minutes sub-interval.

new.description: The number of analyses started by Maestro within the interval.

byClientTool.description: Counts of analyses by client tools used to submit them to the API. Keys of this object are tool names (`TOOLNAME` is used below as a sample placeholder).

TOOLNAME.description: Counts of analyses submitted using the `TOOLNAME` client tool.

total.description: The total number of analyses ever submitted by `TOOLNAME` client tool and hit the cache, as at the interval end.

new.description: The number of analyses submitted within the interval using the `TOOLNAME` client tool, and hit the cache.

total.description: The total number of analyses ever submitted by `TOOLNAME` client tool, as at the interval end.

new.description: The number of analyses submitted within the interval using the `TOOLNAME` client tool.

PARTNER_ID.description: Counts of analyses submitted by accounts owned by (billed to) the partner with `PARTNER_ID`.

new.description: The number of analyses served from the cache within the interval.

total.description: The total number of ever failed analyses at the interval end.

new.description: The number of analyses failed within the interval.

inProgress.description: Counts of analyses failed while in the _In Progress` state.

total.description: The total number of analyses, at the interval end, ever failed while in _In Progress_ state.

new.description: The number of analyses failed within the interval while in the _In Progress_ state.

inQueue.description: Counts of analyses failed while in queue, i.e. after they have been received by API, but before API received and stored the confirmation from Maestro about starting the analysis.

total.description: The total number of analyses, at the interval end, ever failed while being in the queue.

new.description: The number of analyses failed within the interval, while being in the queue.

finished.description: Counts of successfully finished analyses, i.e. those that have not been served from cache, and have not failed.

total.description: The total number of ever completed analyses.

new.description: The number of analyses successfully completed within the interval.

total.description: The total number of analyses queued at the interval end. Note, unlike other `total` fields, this one does not count all analyses even been to the queue, but analyses that were in the queue exactly at the end of the interval.

average.description:
The average number of queued analyses at any time within
the interval. For computational efficiency, for intervals
under five minutes it is just set equal to the `total` (above)
queue size at the current interval end, for larger intervals
this value is estimated based on the total queue size at the
end of each 5-minutes sub-interval.

new.description: The number of analyses added to the queue within the interval.

total.description: The total number of analyses being in progress at the interval end. Note, unlike other `total` fields, this one does not count all analyses even been in the _In Progress_ state, but it counts the actual number of analyses that were _In Progress_ at the interval end.

average.description:
The average number of in progress analyses at any time within
the interval. For computational efficiency, for intervals
under five minutes it is just set equal to the `total` (above)
number of analyses in progress at the current interval end, for
larger intervals this value is estimated based on the total queue
size at the end of each 5-minutes sub-interval.

new.description: The number of analyses started by Maestro within the interval.

byClientTool.description: Counts of analyses by client tools used to submit them to the API. Each field in this object is a tool name (`TOOLNAME` is used below as an example).

TOOLNAME.description: Counts of analyses submitted using the `TOOLNAME` client tool.

total.description: The total number of analyses ever submitted by `TOOLNAME` client tool, as at the interval end.

new.description: The number of analyses submitted within the interval using the `TOOLNAME` client tool.

byOwnerPartnerId.description: Counts of analyses submitted by user accounts "owned" by a partner, in the sence that the partner is to be charged for API usage by these accounts. (`PARNTER_ID` below is a placeholder for a sample user ID).

PARTNER_ID.description: Counts of analyses submitted by accounts owned by (billed to) the partner with `PARTNER_ID`.

total.description: The total number of analyses requested by the stats interval end.

new.description: The number of analyses requested within the stats interval.

cacheHits.description: The counts of analyses served from the cache.

total.description: The total number at the stats interval end.

new.description: The number within the stats interval.

queued.description: The counts of analyses sent to the backend queue.

new.description: The number of analyses sent to execution within the stats interval.

byUserType.description: Counts of requested analyses by the type of users who submitted them.

registered.description: Counts of analyses submitted by registered users.

total.description: The total count of analyses ever submitted by registered users, at the interval end.

new.description: The number of analyses submitted by registered users within the interval.

trial.description: Counts of analyses submitted by trial users.

total.description: The total count of analyses ever submitted by trial users, at the interval end.

new.description: The number of analysese submitted by trial users within the interval.

analysis.description:
Different stats about analyses: average and maximum queue and runtime,
  etc.

time.description: Average and maximum queue and runtime of analyses.

queue.description: Average and maximum queue time of analyses, i.e. the time from an analysis request to the moment it was started by Maestro. Analyses served from the cache are not included here (they have zero queue time, and are not counted here).

av.description: The average analysis queue time (seconds) within the interval.

max.description: The maximum analysis queue time (seconds) within the interval.

median.description: The medium analysis queue time (seconds) within the interval.

avMin.description: The average analysis queue time (minutes) within the interval, i.e. the same as `av` above, but converted to minutes for convenience of reading.

maxMin.description: The maximum analysis queue time (minutes) within the interval, i.e.e the same as `max` above, but converted to minutes for convenience.

medianMin.description: The median analysis queue time (minutes) within the interval.

av.description: The average full time (seconds) of an analysis within the interval, i.e. the full time from analysis request till when its results are ready. Analyses served from cache are not included into this average (for them the total runtime is zero).

max.description: The maximum full time (seconds) of an analysis within the interval.

median.description: The median total analysis time (seconds) within the interval.

avMin.description: The average full time (minutes) of an analysis within the interval. The same as `av` above, but converted to minutes.

maxMin.description: The maximum full time (minutes) of an analysis within the interval. The same as `max` above, but converted to minutes.

medianMin.description: The median total analysis time (minutes) within the interval.

401.description:
Unauthorized — Probably an empty or invalid authorization header sent
with the request.

example.error: Not authenticated; please log in and try again

500.description:
Internal server error — An unexpected error happened at the server
side when trying to fulfil your request.

example.error: Internal server error

get.description: Gets current versions of MythX API and its core sub-modules.

api.description: Main version of the API as a whole.

hash.description: MD5 hash of all API component versions.

429.description:
Too many requests — You have either reached the API usage limit allowed to
your user and subscription types or the maximum request allowed per client and
second.

example.error:
Exceeded plan limit: 10,000 requests in a day; limit will reset in a day;
 Exceeded usage limit; please try again in 24H or upgrade your plan

JWT.description:
The JSON Web Tokens authentication works this way:
- Use [POST /auth/login](#operation/login) to generate a pair of JWT access
  and refresh tokens, and thus to start a JWT session.
- To authenticate following API calls pass the access token, prefixed by
  `Bearer` label, inside the request's `Authorization` header; e.g.
  `Authorization`: `Bearer JWT_ACCESS_TOKEN`.
- Access tokens are valid for ten minutes. To check a token's expiration
  timestamp decode the token, and check its `exp` value. Use
  [POST /auth/refresh](#operation/loginRefresh) to refresh a JWT pair.
  Refresh tokens have one month expiration time.
- To invalidate active JWT pair, and thus to terminate a JWT session
  use [POST /auth/logout](#operation/logout).

MetaMask.description:
Authentication scheme for [MetaMask](https://metamask.io/).

- Get authentication challenge with
  [GET /auth/challenge](#operation/getAuthChallenge);
- Sign it with MetaMask;
- Pass the signed message via the **Authorization** HTTP header of the
  next request to a protected API endpoint. The header value must follow
  the format `MetaMask SIGNED_CHALLENGE`.
